There are several "truths" we need to first establish. Euclid is called the father of geometry just like the diagonal rule is called the Pythagorean theorem and Pythagoras was the first to create and prove it. None of these claims are true but are Eurocentric Western labels. The gold standard in the scientific community for a hypothesis to gain acceptance is the scientific method where the final EMPIRICAL evidence is the final proof. Euclid did a masterful job of compiling several hypothesis and proving them theoretically. In short he completed about half of the scientific method. The ancient Egyptians, Maya, Babylonians, Chinese, Indians, and countless others stated and empirically proved many of Euclid's theorems long before Euclid was ever born.

After the Fall of the Western Roman Empire, the Eastern Roman Empire continued until 1453. It is well documented that the Greek Elements was continually taught in Byzantium, and other Greek states, such as the Empire of Trebzond, Crete under Venice, etc. This reality is reflected in the following quote from Wikipedia on the transmission of the Elements.

"Transmission of the text


In the fourth century AD, Theon of Alexandria produced an edition of Euclid which was so widely used that it became the only surviving source until François Peyrard's 1808 discovery at the Vatican of a manuscript not derived from Theon's. This manuscript, the Heiberg manuscript, is from a Byzantine workshop around 900 and is the basis of modern editions.[7] Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 29 is a tiny fragment of an even older manuscript, but only contains the statement of one proposition."

The Elements has always existed in the original Greek, it was not "shepherded" by the Arabs. This claim is false."

“In the course of my law reading I constantly came upon the word demonstrate. I thought, at first, that I understood its meaning, but soon became satisfied that I did not. I said to myself, What do I do when I demonstrate more than when I reason or prove? How does demonstration differ from any other proof? I consulted Webster’s Dictionary. They told of ’certain proof,’ ’proof beyond the possibility of doubt’; but I could form no idea of what sort of proof that was. I thought a great many things were proved beyond the possibility of doubt, without recourse to any such extraordinary process of reasoning as I understood demonstration to be. I consulted all the dictionaries and books of reference I could find, but with no better results. You might as well have defined blue to a blind man. At last I said,–Lincoln, you never can make a lawyer if you do not understand what demonstrate means; and I left my situation in Springfield, went home to my father’s house, and stayed there till I could give any proposition in the six books of Euclid at sight. I then found out what demonstrate means, and went back to my law studies.” Lincoln

Object Class: Euclid

Euclidean geometry is the linear-based geometry that was developed by the Greek geometer Euclid a little over two millennia ago, the propositions of which were published in his work The Elements.

Subsequent to the publishing of this work, the straight-linear propositions of Euclid were generally accepted by the Greek and Roman academia of the time, and they have continued to be taught as such in all of the schools and (Greek & Latin) universities of the world, up to the present day.

Geometry | Definition of Geometry by Merriam-Websterhttps://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/geometry
Definition of geometry for Students. : a branch of mathematics that deals with points, lines, angles, surfaces, and solids.

Two-dimensional definition and meaning | Collins English Dictionaryhttps://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/two-dimensional two-dimensional. A two-dimensional object or figure is flat rather than solid so that only its length and width can be measured.

Three-dimensional definition and meaning | Collins English Dictionaryhttps://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/three-dimensional
A three-dimensional object is solid rather than flat because it can be measured in three different directions, usually the height, length, and width. ...
Plane; Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia: In mathematics, a plane is a flat, two-dimensional surface that extends infinitely far. A plane is the two-dimensional analogue of a point (zero dimensions), a line (one dimension) and three-dimensional space.

Reality: A plane is not a flat two-dimensional surface, and a flat two-dimensional surface (length and breadth) cannot extend infinitely.

An apparently flat surface has a physical presence, which has a depth to its structure and limiting boundaries to its extent.

In the diagram of two intersecting planes (on my website) what can be seen is that the two planes (as with e.g. two sheets of paper) have three visible dimensions of width, length and thickness (depth), and without the presence of a depth of thickness to the two intersecting planes, combined with the dimensions of width and length, there simply would not be any planes or diagram.

Quote: A two-dimensional object or figure is flat rather than solid so that only its length and width can be measured.

Reality: Objects and figures are not two-dimensional in nature or flat, objects and figures are solid structures which possess three measurable dimensions of height breadth and width, and a visual perspective of angular depth.

EUCLIDEAN SPACE

Quote: A plane is the two-dimensional analogue of a point (zero dimensions), a line (one dimension) and three-dimensional space.

Reality: This statement is both nonsensical and ludicrous, hypothetically speaking and given that the Euclidean assertion that a point has no dimensions is correct, it certainly would not be possible for the nothingness of zero dimensions to multiply from non-existence into either an imaginary two-dimensional plane, or a solid plane of existence, which possesses four dimensions of width, length, depth of thickness and a visual diagonal perspective of depth.

There are three types of what we term as to being space

Drawing - Diagrammatic - Geometric Space

A. The space which comprises the overall size of a drawings surfaces area.
B. The space in-between and separating two drawn items on a drawing surface area.

Voluminous Space

C. The voluminous and empty space which surrounds each of us, our planet and other celestial bodies.

The latter, empty and voluminous space cannot, nor does it of itself, possess any form of dimensions whatsoever, and it is entirely empty and directionless in nature.

As such, and given that it is impossible to draw lines of dimension or direction upon empty air, or within an empty volume of amorphous (shapeless) space.

It is essentially stupid, infantile or entirely disingenuous for anyone to claim, that an empty volume of space of itself, can have any straight linear dimensions or directions within its volume of amorphous emptiness.

And I would also point out to those readers who are of a pragmatic nature; in regard to the latter and relative to the two-dimensional (comic & cartoon) Black Hole and Wormhole theories, which are promoted by so-called theoretical (storytelling) physicist's, as a means of trying to convince (taxpayers) we the layperson masses, that their inane- ludicrous theories are correct.

Holes and wormholes (tunnels) are essentially empty.

Therefore it follows in logic and rationality (common sense), that empty holes and tunnels, cannot and do not exist within the empty volumes of outer-space surrounding all celestial bodies, any more so than holes can exist within our own voluminous oceans of liquid water, here on Earth.
Rhetorical Questions

1. Are electromagnetic particles flat, or are they infinitesimal quanta’s of radiant energy that exist in the form of infinitesimal spheres of spinning and radiating particles of electromagnetic influence?

2. Are atoms flat or are they composites of infinitesimal quanta's of radiant energy orbiting around the central gravitational nucleus of an atom, within the limits of its gravitational field and its surrounding space?

3. Can anything of the physically apparent (macro-cosmic) cosmos be straight or flat, as all physical things of the macro-cosmic universe are constructed from composites of infinitesimal (microcosmic-quantum) electromagnetic (gravitational) particles, which spin and (centrifugally) radiate their spheres of electromagnetic influence outward into all sectors of their immediate surrounding space?

4. Given, that the space surrounding each of us, and our planet, are extents of voluminous emptiness.

How in logic and in rationality can it be claimed, that the mathematical propositions of Euclid’s straight linear geometry, can be applied, to what is essentially directionless non-geometrical empty space?

Euclidean Linear Definitions

Euclid A line is a breadth-less length.

Reality A line is not a breadth-less length in regard to Euclidean and Archimedean linear drawn geometry, as any drawn line must and does, take up an amount of surface area.

A line which can be termed as to being a breadth-less width is a line which exists in two forms.

1. The lines which only exist within our mind’s eye, for example, the imaginary lines that we use to connect the stars of the constellations into linear patterns, and the dots of a hidden drawing quiz into a shape.

2. The visibly apparent lines, that serve to define the shapes of bodies, objects and sketches against a contrasting background.

These lines are not outlines, they are made up of the alignments of atoms that go into the makeups of the surfaces of solid objects, which serve to delineate the overall volumes to the sizes of their shapes, contrasted against a dissimilar colour or texture of background (e.g. the silhouette of the yellow round shape of the Moon, being contrasted against the darkness of the night sky).

And the alignments of atoms that go into the makeups of the edges of sketches and diagrams, which also serve to delineate their overall shapes against a dissimilar and contrasting colour or texture of surface area.

Euclid A point is that which has no part.

Reality As previously relative to lines being a breadth-less width, and in regard to linear drawn geometry, a point possesses a part of the surface area which has been covered over with graphite or a coloured pigment.

Euclid A straight line is a line which lies evenly on itself.

Reality A straight line is a line which lies evenly of itself over an evenly straight flat surface.

Euclid A surface is that which has length and breadth only.

Reality A surface is that which has length breadth and depth.

Euclid The Extremities of a surface are line.

Reality The extremities of a surface relative its shape is its naked edge.
The extremities of surface to a solid is governed by its volume.
The volumes of solid ovoid’s and spheres do not have any extremities to their curvatures of surface.

The Möbius strip or Möbius band, also spelled Mobius or Moebius, is a surface with only one side and only one boundary. The Möbius strip has the mathematical property of being unorientable. It can be realized as a ruled surface. It was discovered independently by the German mathematicians August Ferdinand Möbius and Johann Benedict Listing in 1858. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Möbius_strip

Euclidean: A Mobius strip is a continuous spiral of paper or other material with only one side and only one boundary.

Reality: A Mobius strip is comprised of mega quadrillions of infinitesimal particles and atoms, combined in form of a spiralling continuum that has no length, no edge nor boundary.

In Order Using Simple Arithmetic

LENGTH OF A CIRCLES EDGE
AREA OF A CIRCLE SUMERIA 1000 BC
AREA OF A CIRCLE - ARCHIMEDES TRIANGLE 287 - 212 BC
THREE TIMES R SQUARED 2017
FOUR QUADRANTS 2017 AD
TWELVE STEPS TO THE VOLUME & SURFACE AREA OF A SPHERE
EUCLIDEAN LINEAR DEFINITIONS VS LINEAR PHYSICS

LENGTH OF A CIRCLES EDGE

Using a 120-centimetre length diameter line

1. Multiply the 120-centimeters diameter line by 3
2. The Circles length is 360-centimeters
3. Every Circle has 360-degrees The Circles length is 360-centimeters, and each degree is 1-centimeter in length.
4. Multiply the 120 centimetres diameter line by 4, and the square of diameter line is 480-centimeters, and the circle's length is three-quarters of this length.

AREA OF A CIRCLE SUMERIA 1000 BC

Using a 120-centimetres Diameter line

Multiply the 120-centimeters diameter line by 3

The Circle is 360-centimeters long

Multiply the 360 centimeters diameter line by 360 = 129, 600 square-centimeters

Divide 129, 600 square-centimeters by 12 = 10, 800 square-centimeters to the circles area

AREA OF A CIRCLE - ARCHIMEDES TRIANGLE 287 - 212 BC

Proposition 1.

The area of any circle is equal to a right-angled triangle in which one of the sides about the triangle is equal to the radius, and the other to the circumference of the circle.

The diameter line we are going to use to find the area of a circle according to Archimedes proposition 1, has a 120-centimetre length

The triangles base-line is 60-centimeters as per the radius of the circle

The height of the right angle is 360-centimeters as per the length of the circle

60-centimeters base-line x 360-centimeters circle length yields a rectangle with an area of 21, 600 square-centimetres, which when divided by 2, yields an area of 10, 800 square-centimetres to the area of each triangle and the 120 centimetres diameter line circle.

THREE TIMES R SQUARED 2017 AD

Using a 120-centimetre length “diameter line”

Diameter x 120- centimetres yields 14, 400 square-centimetres to the square of the diameter

Radius 60-centimetre x 60 yields 3, 600 square-centimetres to the square of the radius

Radius squared x 3 yields 10, 800 square-centimetres to the circle, which is ¾ of its square.

FOUR QUADRANTS 2017 AD

Using a 120-centimetre “diameter line”

Diameter x 120 yields an area of 14, 400 square-centimetres.

Divided by 4 each quadrant of the square will be 3, 600 square-centimetres

Divided by 4 each quadrant of a quadrant will be 900 square-centimetres

900 square centimetres multiplied by 3 = 2,700 square-centimetres

2.700 square centimetre multiplied by 4 = 10, 800 square centimetres to the circles area which is ¾ of its square

SUMERIAN METHOD 10,800 square-centimetres

ARCHIMEDES TRIANGLE 10,800 square-centimetres

THREE TIMES R SQUARED 10,800 square-centimetres to the circle

FOUR QUADRANTS 2017 10, 800 square-centimetres to the circle

Four identical results is not a coincidence, and the arithmetic is self-evidently incontestable.

TWELVE STEPS TOWARD THE VOLUME & THE SURFACE AREA OF A SPHERE

CUBE TO ITS CYLINDER

Using a 6-centimetre cube.

1. Measure the height of the cube to obtain a “diameter line” of 6 cm

2. Multiply the diameter line by 6 cm to obtain the area of 36 sq cm to one face of the cube, and a perimeter length of 24 cm.

3. Multiply the area by the length of the diameter to obtain the cubic capacity of 216 cubic cm.

4. Divide the cubic capacity by 4, to obtain one-quarter of the cubic capacity of the cube 54 cubic cm.

5. Multiply the one quarter cubic capacity by 3. to obtain the cubic capacity of the Cylinder 162 cubic cm.

6. Multiply the area of one face of the cube by 6, to obtain the cubes surface area 216 sq cm.

7. Divide the cubes surface area by 4, to obtain one-quarter of the cubes surface area 54 sq cm.

8. Multiply the one quarter surface area of the cube by 3, to obtain the three quarter surface area of the Cylinder 162 sq cm.

CYLINDER TO ITS SPHERE

9. Divide the Cylinders cubic capacity by 4, to obtain one-quarter of the cubic capacity of the Cylinder 40 ½ cubic cm.

10. Multiply the one quarter cubic capacity by 3, to obtain the three quarter cubic capacity of the Sphere 121 ½ cubic cm, to the volume of the Sphere.

11. Divide the Cylinders surface are by 4, to obtain one-quarter of the surface area of the Cylinder 40 ½ sq cm.

12. Multiply the one quarter surface area by 3 to obtain the three quarter surface area of the Sphere 121 ½ sq cm.


EUCLIDEAN LINEAR DEFINITIONS VS LINEAR PHYSICS

Rhetorical

1. Are electromagnetic particles flat, or are they infinitesimal quanta’s of radiant dimensions of energy?

2. Are atoms flat or are they composites of infinitesimal quanta of radiant energy orbiting around the central nuclei of an atom in multi-orbital dimensions within its surrounding space?

3. Can anything be flat or straight, as all things of the cosmos are microcosmic or macrocosmic composites of multiple dimensions of radiant energy, travelling toward or orbiting around a greater central quantity of gravitational energy.?

Euclidean Definition: A point is that which has no part.

Oxford English Dictionary.

Point: (in geometry) something having position but not spatial extent, magnitude, dimension, or direction, for example, the intersection of two lines.

Linear Physics

If as defined a point has no part in geometry, then it does not exist in geometry.
In linear geometry a point may be the beginning or the ending of a linear dimension, or it may be a focal point of convergent, divergent or radiant lines (dimensions).

When a line is drawn onto paper with e.g. a graphite pencil tip, the starting point of the graphite line comes into existence when the graphite is applied to the paper, and therefore starting point has exactly the same width of existence, as that of the rest of the graphite line.

When two lines converge and one crosses over the other, the focal area of the point of their crossing is defined by the two widths of the two lines crossing.

A point which as Euclid states has no part, does not exist in linear geometry any more so than do the linear patterns of the star constellations exist in outer-space.

What he is referring to are the spatial focal points that we all make use of within the mind’s eye of our imaginations, when we are endeavoring to envision in advance e.g. an invention or a structure.

Euclid: A line is a breadth-less length.

Linear Physics

All lines in linear geometry have a width which is defined by the sharpness of the pencils width of tip, the only lines that possess a breadth-less length are as those of the mind e.g. the linear patterns of star constellations.

Euclid: The extremities of a line are points.

Linear Physics

The extremities of a line are their two termini

Euclid: A straight line is a line which lies evenly on itself.

LINEAR PHYSICS

A straightforwardly drawn line can only be considered to be straight, if it is drawn and lies evenly upon a straight flat surface, and as all surfaces are finite so are all lines drawn upon them.

A straightforwardly drawn line on an apparently flat surface is not straight, as the atoms of the drawn line randomly merge with the atoms of the apparently flat surface beneath it.

A straightforwardly drawn line that travels over the Earth's surface curves forwardly over the Earth’s surface.

Al straightforwardly driven trajectory gravitationally curves over the Earth’s surface.

Euclid: A surface is that which has length and breadth only.

Linear Physics

A surface is that which has length breadth and a depth of structure to its area.

A surface has a finite straight or curvaceous boundary to its area, and the same applies to its structure.

Euclid: The Extremities of a surface are line.

Linear Physics

The surface of a sphere is not finite, as it not have any lines or extremities to its surface area.

The structures or the surfaces of bodies and things do not possess lines, as the atoms of their surfaces randomly merge with those of their immediate surrounding (e.g. the Earth and its atmosphere).

In this new century, the limitations of Euclidian geometry, will be increasingly obvious.
Euclid's points, lines, circles, ovals and axioms are outstanding and wonderful for developing left brain math-sequential logic. The engineering of machines requires left-brain geometry, axioms and logic.
However, when students or adults wish to go beyond mere logic as a tool for addressing life's challenges, we begin seeing how limited left-brain-only geometry is.
Callum Coats, a student of Viktor Schauberger, brought the paucity of left-brain-only geometry home to me. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pEwi1NqvGOs
If we look everywhere in Nature, we see forms, volumes and above it all the radiance of the Sun. However the Euclidian geometry of man's inventions since 1750, limited to points, lines, circles, ovals and axioms can NOT reproduce nor produce much insight to the organic forms of Nature. Natural organic forms rarely use points, lines, circles, ovals and axioms.
What do they use? Well, we are still learning about this. One starting place is the polarity of expansion~contraction is a primarily a linear concept, the line expands or contracts.
Even if we demonstrate expansion~contraction with circles-ovals, we are still in only two dimensions. When we start expanding and contracting in three dimensions, we come closer to Nature's geometry; yet, we quickly perceive volumes per se are only a partial geometry of Nature.
Schauberger, thru Callum Coats, helped me see the missing geometry contrasting with volumes is radiance, as in the Sun. A beginning of a Geometry of Nature can start with the polarity of Radiance and Suction. To Learn More: Check out Callum Coats video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pEwi1NqvGOs

The earliest known texts on geometry are the Egyptian Rhind Papyrus (2000–1800 BC) and Moscow Papyrus (c. 1890 BC), the Babylonian clay tablets such as Plimpton 322 (1900 BC). For example, the Moscow Papyrus gives a formula for calculating the volume of a truncated pyramid, or frustum. South of Egypt the ancient Nubians established a system of geometry including early versions of sun clocks. Earliest recorded beginnings of geometry can be traced to ancient Mesopotamia,Egypt in the 2nd mill BC.
